thread.title: North East news LIVE: Latest breaking news, sport, weather, traffic and travel

author: Tom Eden
title: North East news LIVE: Latest breaking news, sport, weather, traffic and travel
text:
Tom Eden Bid for train upgrades 
Rail passengers unhappy at the prospect of a journey in standard class can now bid for an upgrade. (Image: Ian Rutherford) 
Empty first class seats on selected Virgin Trains East Coast services are being auctioned through a smartphone app shortly before departure. 
Prices start from £5 for a seat in first class carriages featuring complimentary food and drink, free wi-fi, reclining leather seats and extra legroom. 
Upgrades are initially available on some weekday services from London King’s Cross to Edinburgh, Leeds, Newcastle and York, with more routes expected to be added shortly. 
Regular walk-up first class fares for London to Edinburgh journeys can cost almost £90 more than standard class tickets. 
Each auction opens approximately two-and-a-half hours in advance and closes around half an hour before the train departs. 
Suzanne Donnelly, commercial director at Virgin Trains East Coast, said: 
“We are really excited to be partnering with Seatfrog to offer customers more opportunities to experience first class. 
“Passengers can get upgrades from as little as £5 and there are real deals to be had. 
“The live bidding element means you can decide at the last minute if you fancy treating yourself.” Benwell KEY EVENT Police swoop to arrest 'armed' man 
Armed police swooped to arrest a man suspected of illegally having a gun in the west end of Newcastle on Tuesday night. 
More than a dozen officers were seen in the Benwell area of the city, responding to reports of a man with a firearm. 
A 35-year-old man was arrested, according to Northumbria Police. 
A spokesman for the force said: 
“At around 6.20pm last night police received intelligence that a man may be in possession of an illegal firearm in the west end of Newcastle. 
“Officers responded and a 35-year-old man was arrested. 
“He remains in police custody at this time.” Politics Is Brexit going horribly wrong? 
Is Brexit going horribly wrong? 
It looks like it may well be. (Image: PA) 
First, the British Government is divided, with Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson battling Prime Minister Theresa May and other Cabinet colleagues. 
Second, a top civil servant has quit from the Government department which is meant to be overseeing Brexit. 
And third, the EU and the UK have been calling each other names instead of reaching agreement.
